II. Purpose of Addendum
The facility has requested an increase in capacity from 44 to 50 male residents, six
through 17 years of age. The facility has also requested to add a program for
Juvenile Delinquents to the facility.
III. Methodology
11/04/2004- Environmental Inspection of three staff offices that are being converted
to resident rooms- “A” rating. Each room will house two residents.
11/17/2004- Fire Safety Inspection of three staff offices that are being converted to
resident rooms- “A” rating. Each room will house two residents.
12/04/2004- Onsite inspection of converted resident rooms.
03/31/2005- Contact- Telephone call received. Talked with Regional Director
regarding proposed change in Program and capacity.
03/31/2005- Received a Child Caring Institution Application requesting a change in
capacity to 50 residents. Received a revised Program Description.
04/06/2005- Modify Terms. License capacity increased to 50 males, ages six
through 17.
IV. Description of Findings and Conclusions
Wolverine Human Services is an established nonprofit Child Care Organization.
Wolverine Center had been licensed since January 1988. The facility has previously
provided short term residential care for abused and neglected males, ages 6 through
17.
Wolverine Shelter has requested to add a Program for Juvenile Delinquents,
because of the need in the community. The facility has obtained a contract with the
Wayne County Care Management Organization to provided short term secure
detention. The security level for all Wolverine Center residents is low security or
community based.
The facility has space to increase capacity and the rooms are in compliance. The
facility is aware of the need to programmatically and physically separate adjudicated
delinquents(non-status offenders) and abuse/neglect wards. This is a Federal Title
IV-E requirement.
The facility submitted a description of the Juvenile Delinquency Program and a
revised Program Statement. The abuse/neglect wards and adjudicated delinquents
will be housed on separate floors of the facility. Initially 20 beds will be used for the
delinquency program and 30 beds for the abuse/neglect wards. Meals and
recreational activities will be separate and education will be onsite in two self
contained classrooms.
2

Direct Care Staff and Social Work staff will receive additional training regarding
working with juvenile delinquents.
V. Recommendation
Based on approved Fire and Environmental Inspections, a revised Program
Statement and Description of the Program for Juvenile Delinquents, it is
recommended that the request for an increase in capacity to 50 and addition of a the
new program be approved.
